content: Our friendly narrator sets the scene: it's a Friday night in November. We're on the Dover road. This should spark some bells for anyone who spent the summer traveling around Europe. Long

column5: in the years before the Chunnel was built

column8: we zoom in on a guy who's supposed to be traveling by mail coach to Dover. A mail coach is a coach that
column9: well

column22: this is because the rider's name is Jerry. We're starting to trust this Mr. Lorry already. Jerry gives Mr. Lorry a letter. All of the other passengers eye Jerry suspiciously. Now that Mr. Lorry's got a letter from Jerry

column26: and tells Jerry to ride back to London to deliver one message: "Recalled to Life." Sound interesting? Just wait. It is! The coach starts off again . As it travels
column27: Joe remarks to Tom that the message Mr. Lorry gave to Jerry was rather cryptic. Tom agrees. They puzzle over it for the rest of the journey.

content: Let's all start with some philosophical reflections

column7: we don't know the people we love. Every man is an island. It's all very existential. Actually
column8: it's all very good writing

He asks the dead man if he'd like to see "her." The man has a different answer for each time Mr. Lorry imagines the conversation. Sometimes he's very happy

38,,As Lucie and her father step out of the courtroom, our narrator takes some time to catch us up on their lives. Dr. Manette is looking worlds better. Our narrator is pretty sure that this is all Lucie's doing: she's brought him back to life. Everyone congratulates everyone else on Darnay's release. Mr. Stryver, Darnay's lawyer, seems to be taking most of the credit for the legal maneuver that saved his life. Of course, that would be forgetting Carton's role in the affair--which our narrator wouldn't want us to do. Unsurprisingly, pointing out the similarity between Carton and Darnay was Carton's own idea. He was the brains behind the operation. Mr. Lorry asks if a man of business" might now approach Charles Darnay. As we quickly realize
column28: however
column29: anytime Mr. Lorry wants to be a "man of business
column30: it rarely works well. He's soon congratulating Charles just like everyone else. Carton, who still seems pretty cynical about the justice system , wants to get out of the general area of the court. He asks Darnay to come out to dinner with him. Aww...a blossoming friendship? Well, not exactly. Darnay can't seem to break through Carton's cynicism. And Carton's already seen how Darnay looks at Lucie. In fact, just because Carton seems to like rubbing salt in his own wounds, he gets Darnay to propose a toast to Miss Manette!" After sharing a drink or two together
column31: Carton's pretty sure he doesn't like Darnay. Darnay sure doesn't like Carton. Perhaps they might even get into blows over Lucie...until
column32: of course
column33: Darnay realizes that Carton has just saved his life. Before they part
column34: however
column35: Darnay wants to know why Carton seems so angry and depressed. Muttering that he's a "disappointed drudge
column36:
Carton says that he's been worth nothing all his life. As Darnay leaves, Carton engages in a little bit of existential self-questioning. Why hasn't he been able to change his own circumstances in life? Why isn't he ever able to change his ways or become a better human being? Tough questions. And Carton's got no answers.
39,,The Marquis' carriage heads out into the country. As he drives, our narrator gives us a description of the land. It's parched and almost dead. All the crops that can be wrung out of the land have been grown and are slowly dying--like the poor people who farm them. Heading into the village, the carriage pauses. Our narrator takes this time to explain why the village looks so crummy, as well. See, the Marquis has been taxing his villagers within an inch of their lives. They don't have the money to buy food or care for their children because they're sending all of their money to the Marquis. In the village, the Marquis pulls aside a man whom he passed on the road. Understandably, the guy's a bit nervous. The Marquis isn't exactly known for his generosity around here. The Marquis demands to know what the guy was staring at when the carriage passed him by a few minutes before. Gulping, the man says that he was staring at another man who was riding below the carriage as a stowaway. Angry and astonished, the Marquis demands to know more. The peasant describes the stowaway as a tall, thin, white-faced man. Gabelle, the town tax collector and postmaster, steps forward to take charge of a hunt for the mysterious man. The Marquis' carriage heads out of town. They've almost reached the Marquis' country estate when a single woman stops them on the road. She's poor and desperate. Her husband has just died, their farm yields no money, and now her children are starving. She's not asking for food, however. She'd just like money to build a small tombstone for her husband. See, the woman is about to die, as well--and she's very upset at the thought that the townspeople won't be able to bury her beside her husband. Right now there's nothing to mark his grave. Without a headstone, no one will know where he was buried. Any guesses as to what the Marquis will do? Exactly. He rides away without listening to another word. Just in case you were wondering, this is exhibit B in the case Dickens is building. Case? What case? Well, we'll call it the Why the Marquis is a heartless monster" case
column37: for now. Hmm...killing a small child and ignoring the pleas of a desperate woman. Sounds like the Marquis is a monster after all. Luckily for him
column38: he doesn't care. His carriage pulls up to a magnificent country mansion. As the Marquis gets out
column39: he asks if Monsieur Charles has arrived yet. Hang on a second...don't we already know a Charles? What's going on here?

column17: he's untouchable. In fact
column18: he might even have some leverage in getting Darnay out of prison. That's why he and Lucie had come to Paris. Mr. Lorry actually agrees. He hurries Lucie up to his room
column19: and then he and the doctor look out the window. Patriots are grinding weapons like mad. The entire courtyard has become stained with blood. Sparks fly off the grindstone
column20: making the entire place look something like a hell on earth. Mr. Lorry whispers to the doctor that the patriots have begun murdering prisoners. Dr. Manette sighs and goes out into the crowd. Soon Mr. Lorry hears the crowd screaming
column21: "Long live the Bastille prisoner!" He watches as Dr. Manette is carried out into the streets by the mob. Later that night
column22: he and Lucie wait upstairs for Dr. Manette to return. Lucie listens
column23: startled
column24: as the grindstone works through the night.

content: Dr. Manette doesn't return for four days. When he finally makes it back to the house
column4: he tells Lucie a condensed version of what he's seen. Mr. Lorry
column5: however
column6: gets the full story: Dr. Manette went to the Tribunal that tries all the prisoners. He announced himself as a former prisoner of the Bastille
column7: and was awarded special status in the Tribunal. From his seat
column8: he saw Darnay brought before the court and almost released. At the last minute
column9: however
column10: the President of the Tribunal got some new information. He ordered that Darnay be held in prison. He won't be executed
column11: but he won't be set free. Dr. Manette describes the Tribunals as madness. There's not any justice or even any attempt at observing any laws. Finally
column12: however
column13: he decides to use all the influence he has to save Darnay. In fact
column14: for the first time since he was released from prison
column15: he seems like a socially powerful man. The doctor becomes the head medical inspector of three prisons. In that position
column16: he's able to bring back occasional news of Darnay. Strangely enough
column17: Mr. Lorry observes that the doctor begins to take pride in his ability to do things for his family. For a long time
column18: Lucie took care of him. Now he's able to return the favor. Nonetheless
column19: despite all the doctor's efforts
column20: Darnay remains in prison. Time passes without any real markers. And now
column21: friends
column22: we're introduced to the real star of this novel: the guillotine. Our narrator takes a good
column23: long time to describe the ways that it influences and symbolizes the new Republic. It's actually a really good bit of the novel--we recommend that you check it out for yourselves. The doctor moves through all the madness of this time. The guillotine chops off heads right and left
column24: Darnay remains in prison
column25: and Lucie...waits.

content: It's the morning of Darnay's trial. Five judges sit at the Tribunal bench. The audience hall is packed with people here to see a show. One woman sits in the front row
column4: knitting. Beside her
column5: Darnay sees Defarge. Dr. Manette sits right beneath the president of the Tribunal
column6: ready to testify. Darnay's charges are read: he's an emigrant
column7: and all emigrants are subject to death. It doesn't matter
column8: of course
column9: that this law was instituted after Darnay came to France. The crowd seems to agree. They immediately call for his death. Darnay testifies that he's been living in England and earning his own money there. He even married a woman in England. When asked
column10: Darnay announces that his wife is Lucie
column11: the daughter of Dr. Manette. The crowd gasps in astonishment. This is an even better show than they'd anticipated. The president asks why Darnay chose to return to France. Darnay explains that he felt a moral obligation to return
column12: even though he'd given up any claim to his own lands long ago. He'd come back to save a citizen's life. How could this be criminal? The audience now agrees with Darnay. They shout pretty loudly to save him. Audiences are pretty fickle
column13: in case you haven't noticed. The president reads Gabelle's letter to Darnay aloud. Now Dr. Manette takes the stand. When he testifies that Darnay had actually been on trial in England for being a foe to England and a friend of the United States
column14: the crowd goes crazy. The French helped the U.S. in the American Revolution
column15: remember? Therefore
column16: Darnay must be a good guy! The jury adds its voices to the choir: Darnay is set free! Crying "Long Live the Republic!" the crowd hoists Darnay on people's shoulders and carries him out of the courtroom. He's like a football hero: no one can get enough of him. Soon
column17: though
column18: the Manettes manage to get him home. Lucie and Darnay fall onto the floor
column19: praying in thanks for Darnay's release. Dr. Manette enters and Lucie runs to him
column20: trembling. Smiling
column21: the doctor tells her to be strong. He's saved Darnay.

content: In England
column4: the Dover mail coach makes its way up a hill one late November night. The foreboding atmosphere of night and mist makes everyone uneasy -- the passengers
column5: the coachman
column6: and the guard. Highway robberies are common
column7: and the travelers are as wary of each other as they are of anyone else they might meet on the road. As the coach reaches the top of the hill
column8: the travelers hear a horse approaching at a gallop. The rider
column9: Jerry
column10: is a messenger from Tellson's Bank in London
column11: and he has a message for one of the passengers
column12: Mr. Jarvis Lorry
column13: an employee of the bank. Mr. Lorry reads the message
column14: which states
column15: "Wait at Dover for Mam'selle."Mr. Lorry tells Jerry to return the answer
column16: "Recalled to Life
column17:
and the coach continues on its way. As Jerry gallops back to London, he muses over Mr. Lorry's mysterious response.
49,,As the coach rattles its way toward Dover, Mr. Lorry dozes restlessly, reflecting upon his mission, to dig some one out of a grave"who has been "buried alive for eighteen years."He envisions what the face of the man must look like and contemplates how severely the years may have affected him. Haunted by visions of the man's face
column18: Mr. Lorry imagines a dialogue in which he repeatedly asks the man
column19: "I hope you care to live?"and the man always responds
column20: "I can't say."

content: Jerry is told to take a note to Mr. Lorry at the Old Bailey law court and to stay there until Mr. Lorry needs him. After arriving at the Old Bailey and giving the doorkeeper the note to deliver to Mr. Lorry
column4: Jerry makes his way into the crowded courtroom. The court is hearing a treason case
column5: punishable by the grisly sentence of being drawn and quartered. The accused
column6: Charles Darnay
column7: stands quietly and calmly before the crowd until he catches sight of Lucie and Doctor Manette
column8: who are witnesses against him. The spectators follow his eyes and are touched by Lucie's expression of fear and sympathy for Darnay.

content: After a waiter at the tavern awakens him
column4: Carton walks from the tavern to Stryver's chambers. The two work on some cases
column5: with Carton doing the brunt of the work. When they finish
column6: Carton and Stryver discuss their school days together and the differences in their fortunes -- how Stryver moved ahead in his profession while Carton remained in Stryver's shadow. The discussion turns to Lucie
column7: whom Stryver admires and whom Carton dismisses as "a golden-haired doll."With dawn breaking
column8: Carton heads home
column9: envisioning for a moment how much richer his life might have been if he had been a man who practiced self-denial and perseverance. Facing the reality of his empty room
column10: he goes to bed
column11: falling asleep on a pillow wet with tears.

content: The same night that Darnay makes his declaration to Doctor Alexandre Manette
column4: Stryver tells Carton that he has decided to marry Lucie. Stryver feels that he is doing Lucie a favor by making her his wife; she is not rich
column5: but she is "a charming creature"who will make a nice home for him. After describing how eligible and attractive he is to women
column6: Stryver chastises Carton for making himself so unattractive to women. He recommends that Carton find himself a wife to take care of him
column7: all the while missing the sarcasm in Carton's replies.

content: Having decided to wed Lucie
column4: Stryver heads to Soho to let her know of her good fortune. On the way
column5: he drops by Tellson's Bank to share his marriage plans with Mr. Lorry. Rather than risk making Doctor Alexandre Manette or Lucie uncomfortable by receiving a proposal directly from Stryver
column6: Mr. Lorry suggests that Stryver let him visit the Manettes and find out if Lucie would accept Stryver's suit. Stryver agrees
column7: and when Mr. Lorry returns from Soho
column8: he tells Stryver that he should drop his suit. However
column9: Stryver has already changed his mind and acts as if the incident was all a misunderstanding caused by Lucie.

content: The night before Lucie's wedding
column4: she and her father sit outside and discuss her upcoming marriage. Lucie tells her father how happy she is and assures him that her love for Darnay will not interfere with their relationship. Doctor Alexandre Manette responds by telling her that marriage is a natural step for her to take and that he is grateful that his imprisonment has not shadowed her life as it has his. He relates to her that when he was in prison he would think of the child he had never known and wonder what its fate was. No matter what he imagined
column5: though
column6: he could never have imagined the degree of happiness that Lucie brought into his life.

content: On the tenth morning
column4: Doctor Alexandre Manette awakens fully recovered and unaware that anything unusual has transpired. Mr. Lorry tactfully conveys to the Doctor what has happened and asks what caused the relapse and how it can be prevented. The Doctor explains that he expected the relapse
column5: which was caused by the revival of certain memories. He believes that the worst is over and doubts that another relapse could occur; if one did
column6: it would most likely result from an intense experience that revived those same memories. Mr. Lorry also questions the wisdom of keeping the shoemaking bench and materials
column7: pointing out that their presence reminds the Doctor of the past that has caused him so much pain. Uneasily agreeing
column8: Doctor Manette requests that Mr. Lorry dispose of the bench and tools without him. Therefore
column9: Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross bury the tools and burn the shoemaking bench after the Doctor leaves to join Lucie and Darnay on their trip.

content: One July day
column4: a stranger approaches the road-mender and asks for directions to the Evremonde chateau. That night
column5: four figures set fire to the chateau and the villagers watch it burn
column6: making no effort to put it out despite the pleas of servants from the chateau. Excited by the destruction of the chateau
column7: the villagers threaten Gabelle
column8: the local tax collector
column9: who hides on his roof while the villagers pound on his door.

content: Despite his personal devotion to Lucie and her daughter
column4: Mr. Lorry recognizes as a businessman that keeping the family of a La Force prisoner at Tellson's could endanger the bank. Consequently
column5: he finds a nearby apartment for them and leaves Jerry Cruncher there to protect them. The day drags on with no word from Doctor Alexandre Manette. Finally
column6: that evening
column7: Monsieur Defarge delivers a message to Mr. Lorry from the Doctor
column8: which states that Darnay is safe for the moment and that Defarge has a note from Darnay to Lucie. As Mr. Lorry takes Defarge to see Lucie
column9: Madame Defarge and The Vengeance join them. Defarge explains that the women want to see Lucie and her child so that they can identify and protect her
column10: should the need arise. After reading the message from her husband
column11: Lucie thanks Madame Defarge and begs her to help Darnay. Madame Defarge responds coldly to Lucie's entreaties. When Miss Pross and young Lucie present themselves to Madame Defarge
column12: she barely notices Miss Pross
column13: focusing instead on young Lucie and casting a literal and figurative shadow on both Lucie and her daughter.

content: After four days
column4: Doctor Alexandre Manette finally returns from the prison. He tells Mr. Lorry how he tried to influence the court tribunal to free his son-in-law
column5: but only secured a guarantee of Darnay's safety. He also recounts the erratic behavior of the mob
column6: which one minute would violently attack condemned prisoners and the next minute would exuberantly cheer the freeing of other prisoners. Feeling strong in his power as a Bastille survivor
column7: Doctor Manette is confident that he will be able to free Darnay. Despite the Doctor's efforts
column8: though
column9: Darnay remains in prison for a year and three months. In the meantime
column10: the Doctor becomes well known throughout Paris and gains status as the inspecting physician for three prisons.

content: At the trial the next day
column4: Darnay offers an articulate and well-planned defense of himself. However
column5: the jury remains unconvinced of his innocence until Doctor Alexandre Manette and Mr. Lorry testify on his behalf. The court spectators who called for Darnay's head at the beginning of the trial cheer wildly when the jury votes to free him. As the crowd swarms around Darnay and carries him home
column6: the rapid change in his situation bewilders him. When he reaches home
column7: he embraces Lucie and his daughter
column8: and he and Lucie pray together in thanks. Afterward
column9: Lucie embraces her father
column10: who is proud of what he has accomplished.

content: The Period It was the best of times
column4: it was the worst of times
column5: it was the age of wisdom
column6: it was the age of foolishness. As its title promises
column7: this brief chapter establishes the era in which the novel takes place: England and France in 1775. The age is marked by competing and contradictory attitudes--"It was the best of times
column8: it was the worst of times"--but resembles the "present period" in which Dickens writes. In England
column9: the public worries over religious prophecies
column10: popular paranormal phenomena in the form of "the Cock-lane ghost
column11: and the messages that a colony of British subjects in America has sent to King George III. France, on the other hand, witnesses excessive spending and extreme violence, a trend that anticipates the erection of the guillotine. Yet in terms of peace and order, English society cannot justify much national boasting" either--crime and capital punishment abound

content: The Mail On a Friday night in late November of 1775
column4: a mail coach wends its way from London to Dover. The journey proves so treacherous that the three passengers must dismount from the carriage and hike alongside it as it climbs a steep hill. From out of the great mists
column5: a messenger on horseback appears and asks to speak to Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The travelers react warily
column6: fearing that they have come upon a highwayman or robber. Mr. Lorry
column7: however
column8: recognizes the messenger's voice as that of Jerry Cruncher
column9: the odd-job man at Tellson's
column10: and accepts his message. The note that Jerry passes him reads: "Wait at Dover for Mam'selle. Lorry instructs Jerry to return to Tellson's with this reply: "Recalled to Life. Confused and troubled by the "blazing strange message
column11:
Jerry rides on to deliver it
62,,Five Years Later It is now 1780. Tellson's Bank in London prides itself on being very small
column12: very dark
column13: very ugly
column14: very incommodious. Were it more welcoming
column15: the bank's partners believe
column16: it would lose its status as a respectable business. It is located by Temple Bar
column17: the spot where
column18: until recently
column19: the government displayed the heads of executed criminals. The narrator explains that at this time
column20: "death was a recipe much in vogue
column21: used against all manner of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to counterfeiters. Jerry Cruncher, employed by Tellson's as a runner and messenger, wakes up in his small apartment, located in an unsavory London neighborhood. He begins the day by yelling at his wife for praying against" him; he throws his muddy boot at her. Around nine o'clock
column22: Cruncher and his young son camp outside Tellson's Bank
column23: where they await the bankers' instructions. When an indoor messenger calls for a porter
column24: Cruncher takes off to do the job. As young Jerry sits alone
column25: he wonders why his father's fingers always have rust on them

content: The Jackal Sydney Carton
column4: the "idlest and most unpromising of men
column5: makes his way from the tavern to Mr. Stryver's apartment. The men drink together and discuss the day's court proceedings. Stryver, nicknamed the lion
column6: compliments his friend, the jackal
column7: for the rare point" that he made regarding Darnay's identification. However
column8: he laments Carton's moodiness. Ever since their days in school together
column9: Stryver observes
column10: Carton has fluctuated between highs and lows
column11: "now in spirits and now in despondency. Carton shrugs off Stryver's accusation that his life lacks a unified direction. Unable to match Stryver's vaulting ambition
column12: Carton claims that he has no other choice but to live his life "in rust and repose. Attempting to change the subject
column13: Stryver turns the conversation to Lucie
column14: praising her beauty. Carton dismisses her as a "golden-haired doll
column15:
but Stryver wonders about Carton's true feelings for her
64,,Monseigneur in the Country The Marquis arrives in the small village to which he serves as lord. There, too, the people live wretched lives, exploited, poor, and starving. As he looks over the submissive faces of the peasants, he singles out a road-mender whom he passed on his journey, a man whose fixed stare bothered him. He demands to know what the road-mender was staring at, and the man responds that someone was holding onto the bottom of the carriage. The Marquis continues on his way and soon comes upon a peasant woman, mourning at a rustic graveside. The woman stops him and begs that he provide her husband's grave with some stone or marker, lest he be forgotten, but the Marquis drives away, unmoved. He arrives at his chateau and, upon entering, asks if Monsieur Charles has arrived from England
65,,The Fellow of Delicacy The next day, Stryver plans to take Lucie to the Vauxhall Gardens to make his marriage proposal. On his way, he drops in at Tellson's Bank, where he informs Mr. Lorry of his intentions. Lorry persuades Stryver to postpone his proposal until he knows for certain that Lucie will accept. This admonition upsets Stryver. He almost insults Lucie as a mincing Fool
column16: but Lorry warns him against doing so. Lorry asks that Stryver hold off his proposal for a few hours to give him time to consult the family and see exactly where Stryver stands. Later that night, Lorry visits Stryver and reports that his fears have been confirmed. If Stryver were to propose, the Manettes would reject his offer. Stryver dismisses the entire affair as one of the vanities" of "empty-headed girls" and begs Lorry to forget it

content: One Night It is the eve of Lucie's marriage to Darnay. Lucie and her father have enjoyed long days of happiness together. Doctor Manette finally has begun to put his imprisonment behind him. For the first time since his release
column4: Manette speaks of his days in the Bastille. In prison
column5: he passed much time imagining what sort of person Lucie would grow up to be. He is very happy now
column6: thanks to Lucie
column7: who has brought him "consolation and restoration. Later that night
column8: Lucie sneaks down to her father's room and finds him sleeping soundly

content: Nine Days Darnay and Doctor Manette converse before going to church for Darnay's wedding to Lucie. Manette emerges "deadly pale" from this meeting. Darnay and Lucie are married and depart for their honeymoon. Almost immediately
column4: a change comes over Manette; he now looks scared and lost. Later that day
column5: Miss Pross and Mr. Lorry discover Manette at his shoemaker's bench
column6: lapsed into an incoherent state. They fear that he will not recover in time to join the newlyweds
column7: as planned
column8: on the honeymoon
column9: and for nine days they keep careful watch over him

content: A Plea When Lucie and Darnay return home from their honeymoon
column4: Sydney Carton is their first visitor. He apologizes for his drunkenness on the night of the trial and delivers a self-effacing speech in which he asks for Darnay's friendship: "If you could endure to have such a worthless fellow. coming and going at odd times
column5: I should ask that I might be permitted to come and go as a privileged person. Carton leaves. Afterward
column6: Darnay comments that Carton tends to be careless and reckless. Lucie deems this judgment too harsh and insists that Carton possesses a good
column7: though wounded
column8: heart. Lucie's compassion touches Darnay
column9: and he promises to regard Carton's faults with sympathy

content: The Grindstone Lucie and Doctor Manette storm into the Paris branch of Tellson's Bank to find Mr. Lorry. They inform him that Darnay sits imprisoned in La Force. Manette remains confident that he can use his standing as a one-time prisoner of the Bastille to help rescue his son-in-law. Lorry sends Lucie into the back room of the bank so that he can speak to Manette in private. He and Manette look out into the courtyard
column4: where throngs of people sharpen their weapons on a grindstone. Lorry explains that the mob is preparing to kill the prisoners. Manette rushes into the crowd
column5: and soon a cry arises: "Help for the Bastille prisoner's kindred in La Force

content: Calm in Storm Four days later
column4: Manette returns from La Force. Lorry notes a change in the once-fragile Manette
column5: who now seems full of strength and power. Manette tells him that he has persuaded the Tribunal
column6: a self-appointed body that tries and sentences the revolution's prisoners
column7: to keep Darnay alive. Moreover
column8: he has secured a job as the inspecting physician of three prisons
column9: one of which is La Force. These duties will enable him to ensure Darnay's safety. Time passes
column10: and France rages as though in a fever. The revolutionaries behead the king and queen
column11: and the guillotine becomes a fixture in the Paris streets. Darnay remains in prison for a year and three months

content: Triumph A motley and bloodthirsty crowd assembles at the trial of Charles Darnay. When Doctor Manette is announced as Darnay's father-in-law
column4: a happy cry goes up among the audience. The court hears testimony from Darnay
column5: Manette
column6: and Gabelle
column7: establishing that Darnay long ago had renounced his title out of disapproval of the aristocracy's treatment of peasants. These factors
column8: in addition to Darnay's status as the son-in-law of the much-loved martyr Manette
column9: persuade the jury to acquit him. The crowd carries Darnay home in a chair on their shoulders

content: Dusk The courtroom crowd pours into the streets to celebrate Darnay's condemnation. John Barsad
column4: charged with ushering Darnay back to his cell
column5: lets Lucie embrace her husband one last time. Darnay insists that Doctor Manette not blame himself for the trial's outcome. Darnay is escorted back to his cell to await his execution the following morning
column6: and Carton escorts the grieving Lucie to her apartment. Carton tells Manette to try his influence one last time with the prosecutors and then meet him at Tellson's
column7: though Lorry feels certain that there is no hope for Darnay
column8: and Carton echoes the sentiment

content: The Footsteps Die Out Forever Crush humanity out of shape once more. and it will twist itself into the same tortured forms. Sow the same seed of. oppression over again
column4: and it will surely yield the same fruit according to its kind. Carton and the young seamstress reach the guillotine. The Vengeance and the other revolutionary women worry that Madame Defarge will miss the beheading of Charles Darnay. The seamstress reflects that the new Republic may make life easier for poor people like herself and her surviving cousin. She kisses Carton and goes calmly to her death. Carton then goes to his. The narrator recounts that those who saw Carton die witnessed a peaceful and even prophetic look on his face
column5: and speculates confidently about Carton's final thoughts: Carton notes the fact that the oppressors in the crowd "have risen on the destruction of the old
column6: but also realizes that, someday, Paris will recover from these horrors and become beautiful. Also in these imagined last moments, Carton sees Lucie and Darnay with a child named after himself. He sees Manette happy and healthy and sees Lorry living a long and peaceful life. He sees a future in which he holds a special place in their hearts and in the hearts of generations hence. He sees his own name made illustrious
column7: and the blots that he threw upon his life fade away. According to the narrator, Carton dies in the knowledge that It is a far
column8: far better thing that I do
column9: than I have ever done; it is a far
column10: far better rest that I go to than I have ever known. I see a beautiful city and a brilliant people rising from this abyss
column11: and
column12: in their struggles to be truly free
column13: . I see the evil of this time. gradually making expiation for itself and wearing out

content: Lucie and Dr. Manette burst into Mr. Lorry's room in the Paris branch of Tellson's Bank. They tell him that the revolutionaries have imprisoned Charles and Mr. Lorry calms Lucie and she goes to rest in another room. Mr. Lorry informs Dr. Manette that the mob is butchering prisoners in the La Force prison. Dr. Manette is famous in that he has survived eighteen years in the Bastille and has some influence over the revolutionaries so he leaves to try and save Darnay's life.
Four days elapse and finally Dr. Manette returns from the prison. He has tried to influence the court tribunal to release his son-in-law
column4: but all he has achieved is his safety for the time being. He describes the situation as very volatile saying that the mob is acting erratically. Prisoners are condemned or freed at a whim. Both decisions bring elation from the mob. The Doctors reputation spreads as time passes
column5: but after fifteen months there has been no change in the situation.

content: Darnay defends himself in the court and makes a well-planned and well-rehearsed defense of himself. Both Dr. Manette and Mr. Lorry testify on his behalf. The spectators are impressed
column4: and cheer wildly when the jury acquits him. He is reunited with Lucie and his daughter who are proud of what he has accomplished.

content: The carts carrying the fifty-two prisoners trundle through the Paris streets and the people crowd round to see Evremonde go to his death. Carton ignores the yelling throng and focuses on the seamstress. He comforts her and recalls the resurrection passage from the Bible. The Vengeance is concerned at the absence of Mme. Defarge. As he mounts the steps towards the guillotine
column4: Carton has a vision where he foresees long and happy lives for Mr. Lorry
column5: Dr. Manette and the Darnay family
column6: all of who will remember him lovingly. He also pictures Lucie and Darnay having a son
column7: whom they call Carton. The bookends with the famous line 'It is a far
column8: far better thing that I do
column9: than I have ever done; it is a far
column10: far better rest that I go to
column11: than I have ever known'.

content: The messenger
column4: Jerry Cruncher
column5: trots off into the darkness to deliver the message to the night watchman of Tellson's Bank. On the way
column6: he stops a number of times to scratch his head and think about the perplexing message. In the coach
column7: Mr. Lorry dozes and dreams about the man who has been all but buried alive in a prison for the last eighteen years.

content: When he arrives at the bank
column4: the clerk tells Jerry to go down to the courthouse
column5: the Old Bailey
column6: and wait for Mr. Lorry. The clerk gives him a note that he is supposed to pass to Mr. Lorry by way of the doorkeeper of the courthouse. The case being tried that day is for treason. The punishment is that the guilty be hanged
column7: drawn
column8: and quartered. Jerry Cruncher thinks the punishment is barbarous. Due to the nature of the trial
column9: a large crowd of spectators has gathered outside the Old Bailey. Jerry Cruncher makes his way quietly through the crowd to the door of the courthouse and hands the note to the doorkeeper
column10: as instructed. A few minutes later the door opens allowing him to squeeze in. The doorkeeper takes the note to Mr. Lorry
column11: who is seated amidst some gentlemen in wigs. Not far away sit two more wigged gentlemen. One is Mr. Stryver
column12: counsel for the prisoner
column13: while the other is Mr. Sydney Carton
column14: who sits with his hands in his pockets staring at the ceiling. Jerry Cruncher manages to catch the attention of Mr. Lorry who nods and signals to him to wait there. The prisoner is brought in. Everyone turns to look at him except Sydney Carton
column15: who continues to stare at the ceiling. The prisoner is a young man of about twenty-five
column16: good-looking
column17: and obviously a gentleman. He is dressed plainly in dark colors
column18: and his hair is gathered in a ribbon at the back of his neck. He is self-possessed
column19: bowing to the judges and standing quietly. He looks around the room
column20: and his eyes rest on two witnesses
column21: a young woman of around twenty-five and a gentleman who evidently is her father. The father looks remarkable due to the whiteness of his hair and the intense look on his face
column22: like a man who is absorbed with his own thoughts. The daughter has one hand drawn through his arm and the other pressed upon it.

content: Mr. Stryvers practice as a barrister has been rapidly increasing
column4: probably due in part to his being loud-voiced and pushy. He is judged to be an intelligent lawyer who can extract the essentials from any information. He is also judged as bold and unscrupulous; perhaps that is why he is friendly with Mr. Carton. The two of them often drink together into the late hours of the night; Stryver drinks for enjoyment
column5: while Carton drinks from frustration. It is rumored that Mr. Carton often goes home
column6: stealthily and unsteadily
column7: at dawn. Carton
column8: who is the most idle and unpromising of men
column9: accompanies Mr. Stryver on every case that he tries in court. As in Darnays trial
column10: Carton sits silently in the courtroom with his hands in his pockets and his eyes on the ceiling. Although Sydney Carton is not aggressive
column11: he is extremely shrewd and helps Stryver plan his defense. Sometimes
column12: he interjects something into the trial
column13: as seen when he throws the piece of paper at Stryver during Darnays trial. It was Cartons cleverness that saved Darnay for the death penalty. Mr. Carton
column14: who is asleep in the tavern
column15: is awakened by a man at ten o'clock as requested. He gets up
column16: dons his hat
column17: and makes his way to the chambers of Mr. Stryver. They go into a dingy room lined with books and littered with papers. A kettle steams on the fire
column18: and on the table sits a large supply of wine
column19: brandy
column20: rum
column21: sugar
column22: and lemons. It becomes apparent during their meeting that even though Mr. Stryver takes all the credit for Darnay's acquittal
column23: it is actually Mr. Carton who had planned his defense. Mr. Stryver proposes a toast to Miss Manette
column24: whom he judges to be beautiful; Mr. Carton calls her a golden-haired doll. When Carton finally goes off to bed
column25: he is drunk and tearful
column26: knowing how incapable he is of taking care of himself or his interests.

content: The Marquis makes his way from Paris through the countryside towards the Evremonde family estate. The crops on the way look dried and withered
column4: just like the peasants. When the carriage stops at a poor village
column5: many peasants are at the fountain washing leaves or anything else that can be eaten. The Marquis gazes with contempt at the faces around the fountain. Soon a dusty road-mender joins the group. The Marquis sends for him and asks what he was staring at when the carriage passed him down the road. The man tells him that someone was hanging underneath the carriage; he says the man was tall
column6: covered with dust
column7: and as white as a ghost. The Marquis is satisfied and drives on. The carriage passes a graveyard where a grief stricken woman begs him for a tombstone for the grave of her dead husband. The Marquis ignores her request and pushes her away. The carriage finally arrives at the estate after dark.

content: Sydney Carton spends many long nights clearing up Mr. Stryver's legal matters before Stryver goes on his long vacation. Finally
column4: on one such night after the work is complete
column5: Mr. Stryver announces to Carton his intentions to marry. Mr. Stryver assumes that women find him tactful
column6: ambitious
column7: and successful and would be happy to become his wife. He thinks that Lucie would be a suitable choice even though she is poor. Mr. Stryver does not mention even once that he is in love with Lucie. Stryver also assumes that Carton is disagreeable to women and informs him of this. Carton is amused with Stryver's attitude and pokes fun at him. Stryver fails to notice the satire in Carton's remarks and aggressively continues his assault on Carton's faults. He finally says that perhaps Carton can marry a commoner
column8: someone with property who will look after him when he ages.

content: On the eve of her wedding day
column4: Lucie is ecstatic and spends the entire evening with her father. As they sit in the courtyard
column5: Lucie assures Dr. Manette that her love for Darnay will never replace or change the love she has for him. The Doctor is now happy about the marriage and states how fond he is of Darnay. One of his fears has always been that Lucie would never know the happiness of a spouse and child
column6: which have provided him with great joy in his own life. He mentions his long imprisonment and how he had often wondered about the fate of his child
column7: still unborn at the time of his capture. Sometimes he would imagine the child to be a boy
column8: who would seek vengeance on his behalf. At other times he imagined the child to be a girl
column9: who looked just like her mother and who would come to visit him in prison
column10: finally setting him free. He confesses that the happiness that Lucie has given him far exceeds the happiness from the children about which he had dreamed. When father and daughter go inside for dinner
column11: they are joined by Miss Pross
column12: who is going to be the bridesmaid. Mr. Lorry is the only other person who will be present at the wedding. After dinner
column13: the Doctor bids everyone goodnight and goes to bed. After a while
column14: Lucie checks in on him and sits lovingly by his bedside watching her father sleep.

content: On the morning of the wedding
column4: Lucie
column5: Mr. Lorry
column6: and Miss Pross wait outside Dr. Manette's room. Inside
column7: the Doctor and Charles Darnay are having a private conference. As they wait
column8: Mr. Lorry cannot stop admiring Lucie; he grows sentimental and teary-eyed as he remembers how he brought her across from France when she was baby. Regaining his composure
column9: Mr. Lorry assures Lucie that he will look after the Doctor while she and Darnay are away on their honeymoon. When Dr. Manette and Darnay emerge from the room
column10: the doctor is shaken and looks deathly pale. Everyone makes their way to the church for the ceremony. After the wedding
column11: they all return to the Manette home. Darnay and Lucie bid farewell to everyone and leave immediately for their two-week honeymoon. It has been prearranged that Dr. Manette will join them after two weeks. When Miss Pross
column12: Mr. Lorry
column13: and Dr. Manette are alone
column14: Mr. Lorry notices that a great change has come over the Doctor. He again appears old
column15: scared
column16: and lost; but Lorry decides to say nothing about it to Dr. Manette. He takes his leave and goes to Tellson's Bank to work for several hours. When he returns to the Manettes
column17: he finds Miss Pross in an extremely agitated state. She tells Lorry that the Doctor has been cobbling shoes. Nothing that he or Miss Pross says or does helps the Doctor snap out of his spell. In order to watch over and help with Dr. Manette
column18: Mr. Lorry decides to take a leave of absence from Tellson's Bank. He and Miss Pross also decide to keep the doctor's reversion a secret from Lucie and everyone else. Dr. Manette continues his cobbling for nine days.

content: Carton drops in to see the newlyweds as soon as they get back from their honeymoon. His habits
column4: manner
column5: and looks have not changed. He tells Darnay that he wishes they were friends and apologizes for the remarks he had made after the trial when he was drunk. Darnay assures him that he has forgotten all about it
column6: especially since Carton had saved his life. Carton then solicits permission to visit them occasionally. Darnay grants him his request. After Carton leaves
column7: Darnay speaks unkindly of him to the others. Later on
column8: while they are preparing for bed
column9: Lucie tells Darnay to be more considerate towards Carton. She feels that Carton is a deeper person with a bigger heart than he shows himself to be.

content: Tellson's Bank in Paris is in a wing of a large house. In front of it is a courtyard that is shut off from the street by a high wall and a strong gate. The house had belonged to a nobleman who had fled France
column4: running away from the troubles of his homeland. The house has been confiscated for use by the citizen-patriots. Tellson's wing
column5: therefore
column6: enjoys a peculiar safety. Mr. Lorry is sitting in his room in Paris on the night of September 3
column7: thankful that none of his friends are here to witness the terrors that surround him. A new revolutionary power
column8: the Paris Commune
column9: has usurped the government
column10: including the police and prisons. Anyone suspected of being an aristocrat or sympathetic towards the aristocratic cause is immediately imprisoned. A tribunal has been appointed to decree summary justice
column11: and the ruthless murder of prisoners
column12: known as the September massacres
column13: has begun. Mr. Lorry's thoughts are interrupted by the ringing of the bell at the gate. Lucie and her father rush inside. He is astonished to see them and wonders why they are in Paris. Lucie informs him of Darnays being held prisoner at La Force. Lucie is sent to an adjoining room so Mr. Lorry and Dr. Manette can talk. Lorry shows the doctor what is going on outside. Thousands of people have gathered to sharpen their bloody weapons on a grindstone. The men using the grindstone are stripped to the waist and are stained all over with blood. Mr. Lorry tells Dr. Manette that the mob is butchering all the prisoners in La Force. He tells the doctor he must act quickly to save Darnay. Dr. Manette runs out to the crowd and tells them something. He then leaves with the mob as Mr. Lorry watches from the window. He goes in to tell Lucie that her father has gone in search of Darnay.

content: After four days
column4: Dr. Manette finally returns from La Force. He tells of the horrors committed there by the mob and the thousands of people that have been killed. He has seen the self-appointed tribunal
column5: which summarily tries the prisoners and sentences them to death. In an effort to save Darnay
column6: he presents himself to the tribunal
column7: one of whom is Defarge
column8: and tells them of his past. He uses all his influence to have a quick and fair trial for Darnay
column9: hoping he will be heard and released. He is told
column10: however
column11: that Darnay will remain imprisoned. While he and Lucie wait for Darnays trial and release
column12: Dr. Manette devotes himself to working as a physician. Before long
column13: he is appointed as the inspecting doctor for three prisons
column14: among them La Force. As a result
column15: he can regularly check on his son-in-law. He is delighted to find that Darnay is no longer in solitary confinement
column16: but mixed with a general body of prisoners. He is also happy to be able to bring messages from Darnay to Lucie. Darnay lies in prison for one and a half years. During this time
column17: a new era begins; France is made a republic -- of Liberty
column18: Freedom
column19: Equality
column20: or Death. The king is tried for treason
column21: condemned
column22: and executed by guillotine. A Law of Suspects is created to allow the government to imprison anyone who is suspected of any crime. A new tribunal is set up and given extraordinary powers to try summarily all those charged with any hostility to the state. A Committee of General Security and a Committee of Public Safety are formed to hunt down and punish political crimes. The Reign of Terror has truly set in. During all these changes
column23: Dr. Manette never stops trying to have Darnay freed.

content: Darnay is brought in front of the dreaded Tribunal. Looking at the jury and the onlookers
column4: he feels as though the usual order has been reversed and that now the felons are trying the honest men. The men in the courtroom are armed with various weapons while the women are wearing knives and knitting. Darnay notices Defarge and his wife; she has a spare piece of knitting under her arm and whispers into Defarge's ear. At first
column5: the onlookers seem hostile towards Darnay
column6: but they respond favorably when they hear that he is married to Dr. Manette's daughter. They are sympathetic to the Doctor and appreciate the work he does. Because of this
column7: their attitude towards Darnay changes from hostility to sympathy. With Dr. Manette's testimony
column8: Gabelle's letter as evidence
column9: and the sympathy of the crowd
column10: Darnay is released. As he leaves
column11: the crowd follows him. They are jubilant
column12: rejoicing
column13: and dancing the Carmagnole; they lift Darnay up and carry him home. Along the way
column14: Darnay looks for the Defarges
column15: but they are nowhere to be seen. At first
column16: he is a bit apprehensive about what is happening and imagines himself to be heading toward the guillotine. This feeling soon passes. Once he reaches home he hugs everyone
column17: kisses his wife
column18: and carries her upstairs. Lucie prays thankfully.

content: Though Darnay is safe for the moment
column4: Lucie feels apprehensive and is still fearful he will be killed. Lucie and her husband stay in the lodge
column5: living modestly. Not wanting to attract attention
column6: they send Miss Pross and Jerry Cruncher to do the shopping for the family. They wonder how soon it will be safe for them to leave Paris. One day Darnay
column7: Lucie and the Doctor are sitting silently waiting for Mr. Lorry when a loud knock is heard at the door. The Doctor opens the door to four rough men in red caps. They have come to arrest Charles Darnay. He has been denounced in the region of St. Antoine by the Defarges and a third man whom they do not identify. When asked by the Doctor what the identity of the third man is
column8: they look surprised and wonder why he
column9: of all people
column10: is asking. They do not reveal his identity and merely say that they will learn everything at the trial the next day.

content: Wollstonecraft thinks that a parent's affection for their children is actually just a blind form of self-obsession. In other words
column4: parents who think their kids are perfect are thinking
column5: deep down
column6: that they are perfect. Mary also refers back to her earlier argument about parents being like tyrants
column7: demanding blind obedience without ever wanting to justify themselves. Wollstonecraft also thinks that parents are extremely selfish when it comes to their kids
column8: because once they have kids
column9: they don't care about anyone else in the world. Family actually breaks down community more than it supports it. The fact is that a good mother has to be able to think for herself and be somewhat self-aware of how she raises her kids. Otherwise she'll just become another overindulgent mother who raises her kids to think that they're the center of the universe. At the end of the day
column10: there has to be a good relationship between parents if the children are going to learn how to properly treat others. And the bond between parents must be based on friendship and not just sexual attraction
column11: because the second one will wither over time.

content: Hetty blushes when the Captain talks to her
column4: and he is captivated by her kitten-like charm. The activity of butter-churning is perfectly suited to showing off her well-shaped arms. He invites the women to a dance on the 30th of June and asks for two dances from Hetty. Mrs. Poyser thinks that it will be much easier to be a tenant of the Captain than of his grandfather
column5: because he is so good-natured that everyone will get new fences and good returns. The Captain gets Hetty alone by sending her mother off to look for Totty. The Captain asks Hetty if she ever goes out walking. Hetty says that she sometimes walks to see Mrs. Pomfret
column6: the lady's maid
column7: who is teaching her to mend lace. She adds that she is going to tea with Mrs. Pomfret next afternoon. Mrs. Poyser returns with Totty
column8: and the Captain asks her if she has a pocket. Totty lifts up her dress to show him that she has one but that it is empty. The Captain gives her five sixpence and returns to find the vicar

content: Hetty has been extremely flattered by the Captain's attentions. She knows that many men like to look at her including Adam Bede
column4: whom she finds quite manly
column5: She also knows that her father would like her to marry Adam. Although Hetty did not like it when his attentions to her slipped
column6: she is not in love with him-especially because he cannot provide her with any luxuries. She is aware that the Captain went to great trouble to see her
column7: but she does not even conceive of marrying him. She is in awe of him and finds him "as dazzling as an Olympian God. On the way home
column8: the Captain confesses to the vicar that he finds Hetty attractive
column9: but the vicar responds that the Captain should not give her airs because he therefore will spoil her for an honest man like Adam. The Captain says that Adam would make a better match with Mary Burge
column10: because then he could take over her father's business. The vicar tells the Captain to look at Mary less
column11: because then he will want her less

content: The dairy was certainly worth looking at is how this chapter begins . Well
column4: that had better be the case. Why else would it get a whole chapter? Yet Arthur
column5: and Eliot
column6: quickly abandon "the dairy" to stare at its pretty dairymaid. Hetty blushes deeply when handsome Arthur Donnithorne appears. Hetty is a babe. Even while she's at work
column7: there's something splendid about her appearance
column8: since "they are the prettiest attitudes and movements into which a pretty girl is thrown in making up butter" . As Arthur looks on at Hetty
column9: he makes her promise him a dance or two at his upcoming birthday feast. All in the presence of Mrs. Poyser
column10: of course. And
column11: of course
column12: with some polite line about how "you must bring all your children
column13: you know
column14: Mrs. Poyser" . Or is he just being polite? Arthur wants to say hello to little Totty . Mrs. Poyser goes to fetch her darling. Arthur and Hetty exchange some small talk about shipping the butter to market. Mrs. Poyser comes back with Totty. More pleasantries
column15: more small talk
column16: Totty shows Arthur the "tiny pink pocket" on her frock
column17: which is
column18: believe it or not
column19: not a euphemism.

content: There's "a slight quarrel" going on among the women of the Donnithorne estate . But Hetty--who'll be our eyes on the ground for this chapter--could care less. All Hetty can think of is her upcoming meeting. With Arthur. As she performs her duties around the Donnithorne estate
column4: Hetty's "little butterfly soul" flutters "incessantly between memory and dubious expectation" . Hetty is hoping to see "Arthur Donnithorne coming to meet her again" in the woods . By twilight she's left chez Donnithorne and is approaching a bend in the forest path where she should run into Arthur. But he isn't there. Hetty is beginning to cry with disappointment when Arthur comes into sight after all. He notices the crying. He's kind as can be. And yet
column5: he feels very
column6: very "uncomfortable" . Arthur departs quickly
column7: yet kindly
column8: and rushes homeward. Yes
column9: this is troubling stuff
column10: this "attracted to a girl you could never
column11: ever
column12: ever marry" business. And Arthur needs a sympathetic ear. He decides that he will "go and tell Mr. Irwine--tell him everything" . He'll be able to sleep easy then.

content: Seth sees Dinah home after the meeting; she is staying with her uncle and aunt
column4: the Poysers
column5: at the Hall Farm. He asks her to marry him
column6: feeling her to be a beautiful soul
column7: full of goodness. Dinah gently refuses
column8: explaining that she wants to live without a family. Her whole life is dedicated to serving others
column9: and she has no heart for considering her own selfish desires. Seth accepts her decision with regret and resignation; there are no hard feelings.

content: Captain Donnithorne and Mrs. Poyser go to the dairy
column4: where Captain Donnithorne first lays eyes on Hetty. A beautiful young girl
column5: Hetty is the seventeen-year-old niece of Mr. Poyser. The Poysers took her in after she was orphaned
column6: and she lives with them at Hall Farm and helps Mrs. Poyser with household chores. Captain Donnithorne flirts with Hetty
column7: even going so far as to ask Mrs. Poyser to go get her small daughter
column8: Totty
column9: in order to have a few moments alone with Hetty. Hetty responds coquettishly to his advances. Captain Donnithorne asks Hetty when she will next be at the Chase
column10: where Captain Donnithorne lives
column11: and Hetty reveals her plans to visit a housekeeper at the estate the next day

content: Hetty walks home by the same route in the woods through which she came. At every turn
column4: she hopes and prays to see Captain Donnithorne
column5: but he is not there. She becomes so anxious that she begins to cry. She finally comes upon Captain Donnithorne
column6: who is waiting for her. When Captain Donnithorne sees Hetty's tears
column7: he asks her what is wrong
column8: and she says that she was afraid he would not come. He is so moved that he kisses her. Immediately after he kisses her
column9: something bitter seems to come between them. When they part at the gate
column10: Captain Donnithorne seems sad
column11: as he reflects on how much his emotions have gotten the better of him. He resolves to go to Mr. Irwine in the morning and tell him everything and in so doing to cleanse himself of the wrong he has committed

content: Hetty's World The narrator decides to go beyond Hetty's pretty exterior to see what kind of a person she is inside. This chapter tracks her thoughts about what is going on around her
column4: but unfortunately
column5: the narrator concludes that Hetty does not have a very large range to her soul. She is mostly concerned with her own material desires. She knows very well that she has suitors. Luke Britton of Broxton comes to church at Hayslope so he can see her. Mr. Craig the gardener at the Chase is wooing her with strawberries
column6: and Adam Bede
column7: who has been invited to Hall Farm for the last three years
column8: is the one favored by her family as having brains. Hetty seems unaware of what she owes her aunt and uncle. She is an orphan
column9: and would have been a servant someplace without their support. Her uncle hopes she will make a good marriage with Adam
column10: who
column11: he knows
column12: will rise by his merits. Hetty only sees Adam as another conquest and enjoys having him in her power. With Arthur's attentions
column13: however
column14: she is already dreaming of greater things. She thinks only of what a man could give her
column15: and she begins to live in a pleasant daydream of how Arthur has looked at her. An uneducated girl
column16: she only thinks of the young squire as a god in her world. She has no sympathy beyond her own situation. On the way to the Bede cottage
column17: Arthur confesses to Irwine how pretty he finds Hetty. Irwine warns him not to flatter her or it will make her unfit for a husband of her own class. Arthur changes the subject.

content: Adam is called to dine with the large tenants and feels uncomfortable leaving his family downstairs
column4: but Seth encourages him to go. He walks up with Bartle. There was a small argument about who was to sit at the top of the table
column5: because the butler felt strongly that the elder Mr. Poyser should. Bartle settles the matter with a joke: the broadest should sit at the head and the second-broadest at the foot. Thus
column6: Mr. Poyser gets the head and Mr. Casson gets the foot. This has put Adam next to Mr. Casson
column7: who thinks that he is too uppity. He asks if it is the first time that Adam has dined at this table. Adam says yes and that he hopes that it is agreeable to the others at the table. A few people say that of course it is. Adam is pleased
column8: anyway
column9: with his seat
column10: because he can see Hetty. Hetty is preoccupied with scolding Totty for putting her feet up on the bench because she might get dust marks on her dress. Adam cannot see the cause of her vexation
column11: but he thinks that she looks sweet
column12: although the moment of anger would not have looked very good on someone less pretty. Mary Burge sees Adam looking at Hetty and is glad that he has seen her out of humor because he might like her less. Hetty
column13: knowing that Mary Burge and Adam are both looking at her
column14: looks up at Adam and smiles brightly

content: The tenants come in to dinner
column4: and they argue over who is to sit at the head of the table. Adam sits with the tenants
column5: even though
column6: as a craftsman
column7: he would normally sit at the lower table. He sees Hetty
column8: who flirts with him because she knows Mary Burge
column9: who loves Adam
column10: is watching them

content: One day

column5: so she could sew a button on her shirt. Lily went to her mom and said
column6: "Mom
column7: I found this needle. Can you share it with me and sew my shirt?" Her mom smiled and said
column8: "Yes
column9: Lily
column10: we can share the needle and fix your shirt." Together
column11: they shared the needle and sewed the button on Lily's shirt. It was not difficult for them because they were sharing and helping each other. After they finished
column12: Lily thanked her mom for sharing the needle and fixing her shirt. They both felt happy because they had shared and worked together.

content: Once upon a time
column4: there was a little car named Beep. Beep loved to go fast and play in the sun. Beep was a healthy car because he always had good fuel. Good fuel made Beep happy and strong. One day
column5: Beep was driving in the park when he saw a big tree. The tree had many leaves that were falling. Beep liked how the leaves fall and wanted to play with them. Beep drove under the tree and watched the leaves fall on him. He laughed and beeped his horn. Beep played with the falling leaves all day. When it was time to go home
column6: Beep knew he needed more fuel. He went to the fuel place and got more healthy fuel. Now
column7: Beep was ready to go fast and play again the next day. And Beep lived happily ever after.

content: One day
column4: a little fish named Fin was swimming near the shore. He saw a big crab and wanted to be friends. "Hi
column5: I am Fin. Do you want to play?" asked the little fish. The crab looked at Fin and said
column6: "No
column7: I don't want to play. I am cold and I don't feel fine." Fin felt sad but wanted to help the crab feel better. He swam away and thought of a plan. He remembered that the sun could make things warm. So
column8: Fin swam to the top of the water and called to the sun
column9: "Please
column10: sun
column11: help my new friend feel fine and not freeze!" The sun heard Fin's call and shone its warm light on the shore. The crab started to feel better and not so cold. He saw Fin and said
column12: "Thank you
column13: little fish
column14: for making me feel fine. I don't feel like I will freeze now. Let's play together!" And so
column15: Fin and the crab played and became good friends.

content: Once upon a time
column4: in a land full of trees
column5: there was a little cherry tree. The cherry tree was very sad because it did not have any friends. All the other trees were big and strong
column6: but the cherry tree was small and weak. The cherry tree was envious of the big trees. One day
column7: the cherry tree felt a tickle in its branches. It was a little spring wind. The wind told the cherry tree not to be sad. The wind said
column8: "You are special because you have sweet cherries that everyone loves." The cherry tree started to feel a little better. As time went on
column9: the cherry tree grew more and more cherries. All the animals in the land came to eat the cherries and play under the cherry tree. The cherry tree was happy because it had many friends now. The cherry tree learned that being different can be a good thing. And they all lived happily ever after.

content: Once upon a time

column9: the cat and the dog

content: Once upon a time

content: Once upon a time

column8: there was a big cheer from the crowd. Tim couldn't believe it. He had done it and he was so proud. He looked back over the junkyard and smiled. He was no longer scared.

content: Benny was at the airport with his mom. He watched as people moved around him with huge suitcases. They made careful steps with the big bags. Mom said

column5: â€œNow I need you to check your suitcase so we can get you on your flight.â€ Benny stared at the little suitcase. He watched as the lady pressed some buttons and then it closed with a loud click. He felt a swell of excitement in his chest and jumped with joy. Mom saw the excitement on Bennyâ€™s face and said with a smile
column6: â€œNow itâ€™s time to take that luggage and go home. Be careful and walk slowly
column7: okay?â€ Benny nodded and carefully held his suitcase as he walked out of the airport. He was on his way home.

content: Once upon a time there were two friends
column4: Jack and Jill. They liked to play together every day in the park. One day
column5: Jack wanted to eat beef for his lunch. But Jill wanted to eat something else. Jack said to Jill
column6: "Let's eat beef
column7: it's yummy!" Jill said
column8: "No
column9: I want to eat something pink." Jack was not happy and they started to play a game of tag. Suddenly
column10: Jack had an idea. He said
column11: "Let's go to the store and buy a pink beef!" Jill was excited and they ran to the store. They found a delicious pink beef
column12: and Jack bought it for Jill. Jill was so happy
column13: and they both enjoyed eating the pink beef together. The friends kept playing in the park and enjoyed their lunch of pink beef. From that day on
column14: Jack and Jill enjoyed playing together and eating pink beef for lunch.

content: Mommy and Jimmy were walking down a path one night. It was dark
column4: and their shadows were long. Jimmy said
column5: "Mommy
column6: look at my shadow. I want to let it run faster than any other shadow". "Oh no
column7: Jimmy
column8: Mommy said, It's too dark outside. Let's just take a look at the shadows for now". Jimmy said
column9: "Okay
column10: Mommy. Let's see how our shadows look like." Mommy and Jimmy watched their shadows stretch across the path. They were long and thin like two dark lines in the night. Jimmy said
column11: "Mommy
column12: look
column13: I can make my shadow go on a walk. It's so fun!" Mommy smiled at Jimmy and said
column14: "Let your shadow go on a walk. I'm sure it will have so much fun!" Jimmy smiled and with a little skip and a jump
column15: his shadow went on its way. What fun they had that night!
